channel.title: Perl Weekly newsletter
channel.description: A free, once a week e-mail round-up of hand-picked news and articles about Perl.

item.title: Business Casual has a Whole New Meaning. Perl role in South Germany
item.description: Online shopping, socializing, working—it’s a digital world now, which is perfect for our client. As an international IT company managing millions of domains for retail and corporate customers in nearly every country in the world, they’re busier than ever—and they need a few senior Perl developers to help them continue to thrive.

item.title: If Jurassic Park has Taught us Anything, it’s that Science is Awesome! Perl in Australia.
item.description: To make it to the inner circle, you need to have modern Perl skills. Ideally, you’ll have an interest in genome technology and bioinformatics. If you spend your weekends reading science magazines and think smarter crops are key to our future, they want to hear from you.

item.title: Free Lunch? Yes, Please. Perl job in Vienna.
item.description: One of the largest product and price comparison platforms in German-speaking countries is on the hunt for a Perl programmer who wants to use their skills to eradicate inflated prices. The successful candidate will relish the chance to join a team that attributes nearly two decades of success to an uncompromising commitment to transparency, objectivity, and quality content.

item.title: Bored of jobs that don't matter? Be a Perl developer and save lives! Cambridge, UK
item.description: This web-app saves lives, and literally pushes forward medical science. Your work will be used by the NHS, research labs, and healthcare providers worldwide to diagnose patients, organize research, and make the world a better place.

item.title: Not your ordinary town! Perl job in Malaysia!
item.description: The client is a financial company whose meteoric growth over the last twenty years means that they’re a solid investment for anyone looking to make a change in location for their career. They started with the idea that online trading should be available to all, and from there, they’ve built a company with multiple locations worldwide.

item.title: German Perl Workshop 2021
item.description: It will be in Leipzig on March 24-26 2021. CFP is open.

item.title: Derrick Talks renv - Purdue Perl Mongers
item.description: Wednesday, January 13, 2021; 5:30 PM EST

item.title: Silicon Valley Perl - Intro to Raku: A New Language for a New Year
item.description: Thursday, January 7, 2021; 6:30 PM PST

item.title: Berlin Perl Mongers
item.description: Wednesday, January 6, 2021; 7:00 PM GMT+1

item.title: Toronto Perl Mongers Online Meeting
item.description: Thursday, December 24, 2020; 7:00 PM EST

item.title: Python Programming Bootcamp for Scientists
item.description: This is an introduction to Python for people who have no programming background. It includes the basics and some tools that are needed for Data Science. I teach this course at the Weizmann Institute of Science. The link here is a coupon that will give a deep discount in the next couple of days. Leanpub offers a 45-day, money-back guarantee.

item.title: Perl Dancer Course
item.description: I started it 10 days ago. It was not easy, but so far I managed to make some progress and record at least one video every day. In the last week my two courses were the best seller courses on Leanpub. I am quite happy with that and I hope they will remain there for the next week as well.

item.title: NICEPERL's lists
item.description:
Great modules released last week;
MetaCPAN weekly report;

item.title: Perl Weekly Challenge 90
item.description: Luis tried rarely used bit operator for mathematica operation. Fun to read always.

item.title: Weekly Challenge 090
item.description: Congratulation Simon for becoming the Champion. Thanks for blogging on dev.to and promoting the cause.

item.title: Perl Weekly Challenge 90: DNA Sequence and Ethiopian Multiplication
item.description: Laurent once again came up with compact solutions. You even get the bonus Scala solution this time.

item.title: Solving Perl Weekly Challenge 090 -- DNA Sequence and Ethiopian Multiplication
item.description: Kang-min made good use of Raku power and made the DNA task looks too easy.

item.title: PWC090 - Ethiopian Multiplication
item.description: Straight to the solution without any discussion.

item.title: PWC090 - DNA Sequence
item.description: One would say there is not much to talk about DNA task. I would recommend Flavio blog to prove my point.

item.title: Multiplication and DNA: Perl Weekly Challenge #90
item.description: Dave made use of deadly combinations of scalar, grep and split. Please do check it out.

item.title: DNA Fragments Are Multiplying Exponentially in North-East Africa
item.description: Colin blog is always fun to read. It is never short of fascinating facts apart from Perl/Raku power.

item.title: Sequenced Multiplication with Raku and Perl
item.description: Arne has been one of the biggest supporter of the weekly challenge. This week also we got to experience Perl and Raku solutions.

item.title: Task 2 - Ethiopian Multiplication
item.description: Andinus showing the power of Raku when dealing with Ethiopian Multiplication task.

item.title: Perl Weekly Challenge 090
item.description: Interesting to know the reference of YAPC 2009 with regard to the DNA task.

item.title: Perl Weekly Challenge 90, Part 2
item.description: Abigail presentation of result of Ethiopian multiplication is very elegant and verbose,

item.title: Perl Weekly Challenge 90, Part 1
item.description: Abigail made the DNA task more fun by reading the sequence from STDIN.

item.title: Perl Weekly Challenge 90
item.description: Aaron with Biochemistry background taught me something new that DNA has direction.

item.title: Perl Review - Perl Weekly Challenge - 088
item.description: Perl Solutions Review by Colin Crain.

item.title: RECAP - The Weekly Challenge - 090
item.description: Enjoy a quick recap of last week contributions by Team PWC dealing with the "DNA Sequence" and "Ethiopian Multiplication" tasks in Perl and Raku. You will find plenty of solutions to keep you busy.

item.title: The Weekly Challenge - 091
item.description: Welcome the new week with couple of fun tasks "Count Number" and "Jump Game". If you are new to the weekly challenge then why not join us and have fun every week. For more information, please read FAQ page.

item.title: Bill & Ted's Bogus Journey
item.description: Ben started interesting discussion about putting debug in test script.

item.title: Strawberryperl.com - https any time soon?
item.description: Is there any plan to get support for https?

item.title: The Twelve Days of Dancer, 2020 Edition
item.description: Jason announced the Advent Calendar 2020 for Dancer2.

item.title: Blogs
item.description: Number of posts last week: BPO: 4; DevTo: 6; Perl.com: 0; PerlAcademy: 2; PerlHacks: 0; PerlMaven: 1; Reddit: 25; TPF: 2;

item.title: CPAN uploads
item.description: Last week there were a total of 269 uploads to CPAN of 154 distinct distributions by 93 different authors. Number of distributions with link to VCS: 132. Number of distros with CI: 57. Number of distros with bugtracker: 92.

item.title: Perl 5.32 from ActiveState - Build your own Perl, the way you want
item.description:
Try out our whole new Perl ecosystem, featuring:
  • A unified, cloud-based toolchain for Linux and Windows (replaces PPM)
  • Virtual environment support (similar to Python's virtualenv)
  • Pure open source licensing (no more ActiveState license)

    • Try ActiveState’s latest Perl release

item.title: #490 - Elevator Pitch Day
item.description:
Hi there

The term "Elevator Pitch Day" coined by one of the respected member of Facebook Perl Programmers group. I liked the idea behind it as mentioned in the post. The core idea is to invite members to organise a virtual meet to discuss all those awesome startup idea out there. It would be nice to find out who we can get to attend that has money/connections/resources to try and make it happen. Would you be interested to join us? I am definitely up for it.

I came across another hate blog post. I am tired of such crap. Although I don't see it as regular as before. I was happy to see few big names responded with facts and figures. We should continue promote the idea of putting Perl in non-Perl blogging site. I have seen a big rise in recent weeks as far as the weekly challenge is concerned.

Lets change the topic and talk about positive vibes. Dave Cross wrote an inspiring blog where he shared the story behind his new module Plack::App::DirectoryIndex. I am confident it would inspire others to contribute to CPAN. Another blog post recommended by Dave talking about how to get started with Windows Subsystem for Linux (WSL).

Couple of weeks ago, I requested the Dancer2 core team to get Advent Calendar 2020 going in the weekly newsletter. I am so happy to see it happening finally. Thank you Jason Crome for The Twelve Days of Dancer, 2020 Edition. It is no longer a secret that Dancer2 is one of my favourite web application framework. Talking about Dancer2, why don't you join the Perl Dancer Course run by Gabor Szabo? It is yet another quality material for all Perl lovers. I am confident you will enjoy it.

Last but not the least, enjoy the festive season keeping safe distance.
